conclusion: To solve the problem, we need to determine the magnitude of the pressure exerted by the sled on the ground.
We start by analyzing the forces acting on the sled.
The figure shows a child sitting on a sled being pulled by an adult with a force \( F \) at an angle \( \theta \) above the horizontal.

The forces acting on the sled are: the weight of the child and sled \( W \), the normal force \( N \), the vertical component of the applied force \( F \sin \theta \), and the horizontal component \( F \cos \theta \).
The total mass of the sled and the child is \( m_{\text{total}} = m_{\text{child}} + m_{\text{sled}} = 30\, \text{kg} + 10\, \text{kg} = 40\, \text{kg} \).
The weight of the sled and the child is \( W = m_{\text{total}} g = 40\, \text{kg} \times 10\, \text{m/s}^2 = 400\, \text{N} \).
The horizontal component of the force \( F \) is \( F \cos \theta \), and the vertical component is \( F \sin \theta \).
Since the sled is moving at a constant speed, the net force in the horizontal direction is zero: \( F \cos \theta - f = 0 \implies f = F \cos \theta \).
The net force in the vertical direction is zero: \( N + F \sin \theta - W = 0 \implies N = W - F \sin \theta \).
The horizontal component of the force is \( F \cos \theta = 100\, \text{N} \times \cos 37^\circ = 100\, \text{N} \times 0.8 = 80\, \text{N} \).
The vertical component of the force is \( F \sin \theta = 100\, \text{N} \times \sin 37^\circ = 100\, \text{N} \times 0.6 = 60\, \text{N} \).
The normal force is \( N = W - F \sin \theta = 400\, \text{N} - 60\, \text{N} = 340\, \text{N} \).
The pressure exerted by the sled on the ground is equal to the normal force \( N = 340\, \text{N} \).
The magnitude of the pressure exerted by the sled on the ground is \( \boxed{340\, \text{N}} \).
